newsitem.title: USA: Citrix falls on possible Microsoft rivalry.
newsitem.headline: Citrix falls on possible Microsoft rivalry.

text.p: Shares of Citrix Systems Inc lost almost 60 percent of their value after the company said late Wednesday that its core products may face competition from industry behemoth Microsoft Corp.

Late Wednesday, Citrix said that during recent licensing talks, Microsoft told Citrix it could develop certain features in its increasingly popular Windows NT operating system that would compete with Citrix's chief products. Microsoft said if talks broke down, it could develop the features internally, or seek another source for the technology.
Citrix's shares tumbled 15 to 11-1/4 in heavy trading.
The company said that if Microsoft decided to develop these features that would compete with Citrix's WinFrame technology, it would result in a material adverse financial condition for Citrix.
"It's getting hammered," said Arnie Owen, director of equities trading at Kaufman Brothers. "It's all related to the Microsoft fears. The stock is just falling out of bed."

Officials at Citrix, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., were not immediately available. In a statement late Wednesday, Citrix said there can be no assurance that a cross-licensing deal with Microsoft can be entered into.

Last month, Citrix reported record revenues of $15.6 million in the fourth quarter, up from $5.2 million in the year-ago quarter. The company said that its strong quarter reflected the strong momentum in the Windows NT marketplace.
